questions.text: The pharynx, funnel-shaped tube,15 cm long is widest :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Opposite the Hyoid Bone The pharynx is a funnel-shaped muscular tube, approximately 15 cm long, extending from the base of the skull to the esophagus. It is widest at the level of the hyoid bone, where its diameter is about 5 cm. Below this level, the pharynx gradually narrows as it transitions into the esophagus at the cricoid cartilage (C6 level). This anatomical widening allows for the passage of air and food, aiding in swallowing and respiration. Incorrect Options: (A) Opposite the Skull Base At the skull base, the pharynx is relatively narrow, measuring about 2.5 cm in diameter. This area includes the nasopharynx, which connects to the nasal cavity via the choanae. (B) Opposite the Styloid Process The styloid process is a bony projection from the temporal bone, and while it provides attachment for muscles and ligaments related to the pharynx, it is not the widest point of the pharynx. (D) Opposite the Thyroid Cartilage At the level of the thyroid cartilage (C4-C5 level), the pharynx narrows as it approaches the laryngopharynx and esophageal opening. This is not its widest part.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with cervical lymphadenopathy with recurrent epistaxis. Most likely cause is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma Nasopharynx Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a malignant tumor arising from the nasopharyngeal epithelium, commonly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). It frequently presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy as the first symptom due to early metastasis to regional lymph nodes. Recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds) occurs due to tumor invasion into the vascular mucosa of the nasopharynx. Other symptoms include nasal obstruction, hearing loss (due to eustachian tube involvement), headache, and cranial nerve palsies. NPC is common in older adults and has a higher prevalence in Southeast Asia and China. Incorrect Options: (A) Angiofibroma Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but highly vascular tumor. It commonly affects adolescent males (10–25 years) rather than elderly patients. Symptoms include recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction, but it does not present with cervical lymphadenopathy like NPC. (C) Rhabdomyosarcoma Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor that is more common in children and young adults, not in older patients. It can arise in the head and neck region, but it rarely causes recurrent epistaxis. Lymph node involvement can occur, but it is not as characteristic as in NPC. (D) None Since nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is the most likely cause given the age, cervical lymphadenopathy, and recurrent epistaxis

choices.text: Weber Fergusson’s transmaxillary approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen is the most common site of origin

questions.text: All of the following are true about juvenile angiofibroma except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Weber Fergusson’s transmaxillary approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx (Incorrect Statement) Weber-Fergusson’s transmaxillary approach is a radical open surgical approach used for extensive tumors involving the infratemporal fossa, orbit, or skull base. For tumors limited to the nose and nasopharynx, endoscopic endonasal resection is preferred due to less morbidity, faster recovery, and better cosmesis. Open approaches like Weber-Fergusson’s incision are now reserved for advanced-stage angiofibromas. Incorrect Options: (A) Frog face deformity (True Statement) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but highly vascular tumor seen in adolescent males (10-25 years old). Large tumors extending into the infratemporal fossa can cause bilateral cheek swelling, leading to a "frog-face" deformity due to pterygoid plate involvement. (C) Flutamide can induce tumor shrinkage (True Statement) Flutamide, an anti-androgen drug, has been shown to induce tumor shrinkage in JNA, as the tumor is androgen-dependent. It may be used as neoadjuvant therapy before surgery to reduce tumor size and vascularity. (D) Superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen is the most common site of origin (True Statement) The sphenopalatine foramen (posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity) is the most common site of origin of JNA. The tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa, infratemporal fossa, and skull base as it enlarges.

questions.text: Trotters triad is seen in carcinoma of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (Correct Answer) Trotter’s Triad is a clinical presentation associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It consists of: Unilateral conductive hearing loss – Due to Eustachian tube obstruction, leading to serous otitis media. Trismus (difficulty in mouth opening) – Due to invasion of the pterygoid muscles. Palatal paralysis – Due to involvement of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), affecting the tensor veli palatini muscle. NPC commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and recurrent epistaxis. Incorrect Options: (A) Maxillary Carcinoma Carcinoma of the maxilla (maxillary sinus malignancy) presents with: Facial swelling, cheek numbness (due to infraorbital nerve involvement), nasal obstruction, and epistaxis. It does not typically cause Trotter’s Triad. (B) Laryngeal Carcinoma Laryngeal cancer commonly presents with: Progressive hoarseness, stridor, difficulty swallowing, and airway obstruction. It does not cause trismus or palatal paralysis. (D) Ethmoid Sinus Carcinoma Ethmoid sinus malignancy presents with: Proptosis, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and diplopia due to orbital invasion. It is not associated with Trotter’s Triad.

questions.text: Most common site of tumor in the nasopharynx:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fossa of Rosenmüller (Correct Answer) The Fossa of Rosenmüller is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It is a recess located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, behind the torus tubarius (near the opening of the Eustachian tube). NPC often arises from the pharyngeal recess (Fossa of Rosenmüller) due to its lymphoid-rich mucosa, which makes it susceptible to malignant transformation. Patients typically present with: Unilateral conductive hearing loss (due to Eustachian tube obstruction → serous otitis media). Nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Cervical lymphadenopathy (first sign in many cases). Incorrect Options: (A) Eustachian tubes The nasopharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube is often obstructed by nasopharyngeal tumors, leading to middle ear effusion. However, the tumor typically arises from the Fossa of Rosenmüller, not the Eustachian tube itself. (C) Base of tongue The base of the tongue is part of the oropharynx, not the nasopharynx. Tumors in this region are usually oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas, not nasopharyngeal carcinomas. (D) Post-cricoid space The post-cricoid space is part of the hypopharynx, not the nasopharynx. Tumors here are usually associated with hypopharyngeal carcinoma, not nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: An inner longitudinal layer of pharynx includes all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Inferior Constrictor The inferior constrictor muscle is part of the outer circular muscle layer of the pharynx, not the inner longitudinal layer. The pharyngeal musculature consists of two layers: Outer circular layer → Includes superior, middle, and inferior constrictor muscles. Inner longitudinal layer → Includes Stylopharyngeus, Palatopharyngeus, and Salpingopharyngeus. The inferior constrictor helps in peristaltic movement during swallowing by contracting sequentially with the superior and middle constrictors. Incorrect Options: (A) Stylopharyngeus Originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. Innervated by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) – the only pharyngeal muscle supplied by CN IX. Functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speech. (B) Palatopharyngeus Originates from the hard palate and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. Innervated by the Vagus nerve (CN X) via the pharyngeal plexus. Helps in elevating the pharynx and closing the nasopharynx during swallowing. (C) Salpingopharyngeus Originates from the cartilaginous part of the Eustachian tube and merges with the palatopharyngeus muscle. Innervated by the Vagus nerve (CN X) via the pharyngeal plexus. Functions to equalize middle ear pressure by opening the Eustachian tube and assisting in swallowing.

questions.text: Interdigitating superior constrictor muscles that form a band at the posterior pharyngeal wall:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Passavant’s Ridge (Correct Answer) Passavant’s Ridge is a muscular ridge formed by the interdigitating fibers of the superior constrictor muscle and the palatopharyngeus muscle. It appears on the posterior pharyngeal wall during swallowing or speech. It helps in velopharyngeal closure, which is essential for preventing nasal regurgitation of food and ensuring proper speech articulation. It is particularly prominent in individuals with velopharyngeal insufficiency (e.g., cleft palate). Incorrect Options: (B) Rathke’s Pouch Cyst A remnant of Rathke’s pouch, which is an embryological structure involved in pituitary gland development. It is located in the sellar or suprasellar region, not in the pharyngeal wall. Can cause pituitary dysfunction and visual disturbances, but not related to the superior constrictor muscle. (C) Sinus of Morgagni A gap between the superior constrictor muscle and the skull base, located at the lateral part of the pharyngeal wall. It serves as a passage for the Eustachian tube and the levator veli palatini muscle. Not a muscular ridge, so it is not associated with the interdigitating superior constrictor muscles. (D) Torus Tubarius A cartilaginous elevation surrounding the opening of the Eustachian tube in the nasopharynx. Helps in equalizing middle ear pressure, but it is not formed by the superior constrictor muscle.

questions.text: Which of the structure crosses through sinus of morgagni:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tensor veli palatini (Correct Answer) The Sinus of Morgagni is a gap between the skull base and the superior constrictor muscle located at the lateral part of the pharyngeal wall. It allows passage for several structures, including: Tensor veli palatini muscle Eustachian tube (auditory tube) Levator veli palatini muscle Tensor veli palatini functions to tense the soft palate and open the Eustachian tube, aiding in pressure equalization between the middle ear and nasopharynx. Incorrect Options: (A) Stapedius The stapedius muscle is the smallest skeletal muscle in the body and is located in the middle ear. It attaches to the stapes bone and functions to dampen excessive vibrations caused by loud sounds. It does not pass through the Sinus of Morgagni. (C) Tensor tympani This muscle is located in the middle ear and attaches to the malleus. It functions to dampen sound vibrations by reducing movement of the tympanic membrane. It does not pass through the Sinus of Morgagni. (D) Chorda Tympani The Chorda Tympani is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII) that carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It passes through the middle ear but is not related to the Sinus of Morgagni.

choices.text: Physiological enlargement continues upto 6 years of age
Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in submucous cleft palate
Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

questions.text: Not a true statement regarding adenoids
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy Digital palpation was historically used to assess adenoid size, but it is now avoided due to: Risk of injury and bleeding Possible infection spread Patient discomfort Instead, nasal endoscopy or lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx is preferred for assessment. Incorrect Options: (A) Physiological enlargement continues up to 6 years of age Correct Statement: Adenoids start growing from birth, reach their maximum size around 5-6 years, and begin to involute by adolescence. This enlargement is part of the normal immune development in children. (B) Adenoids do not have a capsule Correct Statement: Unlike palatine tonsils, adenoids lack a complete fibrous capsule. They are covered by a thin mucosal layer, making them more diffusely spread. (C) Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in submucous cleft palate Correct Statement: In submucous cleft palate, the adenoids help in velopharyngeal closure. Removing them can worsen velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI), leading to nasal speech and regurgitation. Therefore, adenoidectomy is contraindicated in such cases unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: Adenoids are prominent in children upto :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6 years Adenoids are most prominent between the ages of 3 to 6 years. They begin to grow after birth, reach their maximum size around 5-6 years, and then gradually involute. By adolescence (12-16 years), adenoids usually shrink significantly and may completely regress. Incorrect Options: (A) 4 years Adenoids are still growing at this stage and usually reach their peak size by 5-6 years. (C) 10 years By this age, adenoids typically start regressing, although in some children, they may persist and remain enlarged. (D) 14 years By adolescence, adenoids usually shrink significantly or even disappear completely. Persistent large adenoids beyond this age are uncommon.

questions.text: Tonsils of Gerlach are related with :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tubal tonsil Tonsils of Gerlach refer to the tubal tonsils, which are part of Waldeyer’s ring. These lymphoid structures are located around the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube. They play a role in immune defense by trapping pathogens entering through the nasopharynx. Incorrect Options: (A) Lingual tonsil The lingual tonsil is located at the base of the tongue and is not related to Gerlach’s tonsils. (C) Faucial tonsil The faucial tonsils (palatine tonsils) are located in the oropharynx, between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches. They are not associated with the tubal tonsils. (D) Luschka’s tonsil Luschka’s tonsil refers to the pharyngeal tonsil (adenoids) located in the nasopharynx, which is different from the tubal tonsils.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form Waldeyer’s ring?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Jugulodigastric node The jugulodigastric node is a deep cervical lymph node, not a part of Waldeyer’s ring. Waldeyer’s ring is a mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) structure in the pharynx, whereas the jugulodigastric node is a lymph node in the neck involved in drainage but not directly part of the ring. Incorrect Options: (A) Palatine Tonsils The palatine tonsils are located on either side of the oropharynx and are a major component of Waldeyer’s ring. (B) Adenoids The adenoids (pharyngeal tonsils or Luschka’s tonsils) are located in the nasopharynx and form the superior part of Waldeyer’s ring. (D) Lateral Pharyngeal Bands These lymphoid aggregates are located in the lateral walls of the pharynx and are considered part of Waldeyer’s ring.
